definitions: distribute or listen to episodic digital audio content through internet streaming or downloads
produce and record audio programs for online distribution to subscribers
examples: They podcast their interviews every Monday morning regularly
Many educators podcast their lectures for remote students
She decided to podcast about sustainable living practices
The team podcasts weekly episodes about technology trends

definitions: extend one's finger or an object to indicate a specific direction or location
draw someone's attention to something important by verbal or gestural indication
aim or direct a weapon or tool at a specific target
make the end of something sharp or more tapered
examples: She pointed toward the distant mountain peak clearly
The compass needle always points to magnetic north
The teacher pointed out several errors in the essay
He pointed to the evidence supporting his argument
The hunter carefully pointed his rifle at the target
She pointed the camera directly at the sunset
The craftsman pointed the wooden stakes before installation
They pointed their pencils before the drawing class

definitions: hold or balance something in a steady position with careful control
prepare oneself mentally or emotionally for something challenging or important
position oneself or something in readiness for action or movement
examples: The gymnast poised herself perfectly on the beam
He poised the delicate vase on the narrow shelf
She poised herself for the difficult conversation ahead
The actor poised himself before entering the stage
The diver poised on the edge of the platform
The cat poised to pounce on its prey

definitions: give someone or something a poisonous substance to cause illness or death
contaminate or pollute something with harmful or toxic substances making it dangerous
have a harmful corrupting influence on someone's mind attitudes or relationships
examples: Someone tried to poison the king's wine deliberately
The villain poisoned his rival with arsenic secretly
Industrial waste poisoned the river killing all fish
Lead paint can poison children who ingest it
Jealousy slowly poisoned their once happy marriage completely
False rumors poisoned the community against the newcomers

definitions: push or jab someone or something quickly with a finger or pointed object
push or thrust something through an opening or to emerge from somewhere
search through or investigate something in a casual or nosy manner
examples: The child poked his sister to get her attention
She poked the fire with a long metal stick
His head poked through the doorway looking around curiously
Flowers poked through the snow in early spring
Stop poking around in my personal belongings please
Reporters were poking into the politician's private life

definitions: propel a boat or raft by pushing against the bottom with a long pole
support or prop something up using poles or vertical supports
examples: They poled the punt along the shallow river slowly
The guide poled the raft through the marshy waters
Workers poled the heavy canvas tent before the event
They poled the tomato plants to keep them upright

definitions: maintain law and order in an area through authorized enforcement activities
monitor and enforce compliance with rules regulations or agreements
patrol or guard an area to ensure security and prevent problems
examples: Officers police the downtown area twenty-four hours daily
The UN forces police the ceasefire zone carefully
Regulators police the financial markets for illegal activities
The committee polices adherence to the competition rules
Security guards police the parking lot during concerts
Volunteers police the beach to protect nesting turtles

definitions: rub something with a cloth or substance to make it smooth and shiny
improve or refine skills abilities or techniques through practice and attention
make something more sophisticated refined or perfect through careful work
examples: She polished the silver until it gleamed brightly
He polished his shoes every Sunday morning carefully
The pianist polished her technique through daily practice
Athletes polish their skills during intensive training sessions
The editor helped polish the manuscript before publication
They polished the presentation for the board meeting

definitions: perform a lively dance in duple time with a hop-step pattern
examples: The couple polkaed energetically around the dance floor
Everyone polkaed at the traditional wedding celebration joyfully

definitions: question people systematically to gather opinions data or voting preferences
receive a specified number or proportion of votes in an election
cut short or trim especially hair or horns of animals
examples: Researchers polled residents about the proposed development project
The company polls customers quarterly about service satisfaction
The candidate polled forty percent in the primary
The initiative polled enough votes to pass easily
Farmers poll their cattle's horns for safety reasons
They polled the hedge to promote thicker growth

definitions: transfer pollen from one flower to another enabling plant reproduction naturally
deliberately transfer pollen to fertilize plants in controlled cultivation
examples: Bees pollinate flowers as they collect nectar daily
Wind pollinates many grass and tree species naturally
Farmers pollinate greenhouse tomatoes using special brushes carefully
Scientists pollinate experimental plants to create new hybrids

definitions: contaminate the environment with harmful or poisonous substances damaging ecosystems
corrupt or defile something pure or sacred with unwholesome influences
examples: Factories pollute rivers with toxic chemical waste daily
Vehicle emissions pollute the air in crowded cities
Violence in media pollutes young minds according to critics
Greed pollutes the noble intentions of public service

definitions: strike or beat someone or something repeatedly with fists or blows
examples: The boxer pommeled his opponent against the ropes
Heavy rain pommeled the roof throughout the night

definitions: think about something carefully deeply and at length before making a decision
examples: She pondered the job offer for several days
The committee pondered various solutions to the problem

definitions: express opinions in a pompous dogmatic way as if they were undeniably correct
examples: The professor pontificated about politics during every lecture
He pontificates endlessly about subjects he barely understands

definitions: combine money resources or efforts from different sources for shared use
collect or accumulate in one place forming a pool or reserve
examples: The neighbors pooled their money to repair the fence
Companies pooled resources to fund the research project
Water pooled in the low areas after rain
Blood pooled beneath the surface creating dark bruises

definitions: make a sharp explosive sound or cause something to burst suddenly
appear or emerge suddenly and unexpectedly from somewhere
move quickly and suddenly in a specified direction
go somewhere quickly or briefly for a short visit
examples: The balloon popped when it touched the thorn
She popped the bubble wrap between her fingers
A rabbit popped out from behind the bush
His eyes popped wide with surprise and amazement
She popped into the kitchen for some water
The cork popped out of the champagne bottle
I'll pop over to see you this afternoon
He popped into the store for some milk

definitions: make something widely known liked or fashionable among the general public
make complex ideas or specialized knowledge accessible and appealing to ordinary people
examples: Television helped popularise American culture around the world
Social media popularised the dance trend within weeks
Carl Sagan popularised astronomy through his television series
The author popularised quantum physics for general readers

definitions: make something widely known liked or fashionable among the general public
make complex ideas or specialized knowledge accessible and appealing to ordinary people
examples: Television helped popularize American culture around the world
Social media popularized the dance trend within weeks
Carl Sagan popularized astronomy through his television series
The author popularized quantum physics for general readers

definitions: live in or establish a population in a particular place or area
fill a database form or system with data or information
examples: Settlers gradually populated the western territories during expansion
Various species populate the tropical rainforest ecosystem abundantly
The program automatically populates fields with customer information
Developers populate the database with test data first

definitions: read or study something very carefully and attentively for extended periods
examples: She pored over the ancient manuscripts for hours
Students pore over textbooks before their final exams

definitions: carry or hold something in a particular position especially military arms
transfer software or data from one system or platform to another
turn a ship or its helm to the port side
examples: Soldiers port arms during the ceremonial parade precisely
The honor guard ported their rifles in perfect unison
Developers ported the game to multiple gaming consoles
They successfully ported the application to mobile devices
The captain ordered them to port the helm immediately
They ported to avoid the approaching vessel quickly

definitions: work as a porter carrying luggage or goods for payment at stations hotels or markets
examples: He portered at the railway station for twenty years
Students porter during summer breaks to earn extra money

definitions: divide something into parts or shares for distribution
distribute or allocate something in appropriate amounts or proportions
examples: The chef carefully portioned the meal for each guest
She portioned the inheritance equally among her children
They portioned out supplies according to each family's needs
The teacher portioned assignments based on student abilities

definitions: depict someone or something in a work of art literature or performance
describe or represent the character or qualities of someone or something
represent or describe someone or something in a particular way often misleadingly
examples: The actor brilliantly portrayed the historical figure on stage
The painting portrays a peaceful rural scene beautifully
The biography portrays her as a complex individual
The documentary portrays life in remote villages accurately
Media often portrays teenagers as irresponsible and reckless
Politicians portray their opponents in negative ways deliberately

definitions: position oneself or be positioned for a photograph portrait or artistic work
present or constitute a problem danger or question requiring consideration
pretend to be someone or something that one is not
examples: The model posed for three hours during the session
The family posed together for their annual portrait
Rising sea levels pose a threat to coastal cities
This situation poses serious questions about security policy
The spy posed as a journalist to gather information
She posed as an expert though she lacked credentials

definitions: put forward or suggest a theory idea or argument for consideration
assume the existence or truth of something as a basis for reasoning
examples: The scientist posited a new theory about dark matter
Philosophers posit various explanations for human consciousness
Let's posit that the market will recover next year
The model posits constant economic growth over time

definitions: put or arrange someone or something in a particular place or position strategically
place or arrange something in relation to other things for best advantage
examples: The general positioned his troops along the ridge
She positioned herself near the exit door carefully
The company positioned its product as premium quality
They positioned the furniture to maximize space efficiently

definitions: have or own something as property or under one's control
have a particular quality characteristic ability or feature
have complete power over someone's mind or spirit as if by supernatural means
examples: She possesses several valuable paintings from famous artists
The museum possesses the largest collection of artifacts
He possesses remarkable talent for learning new languages
The region possesses abundant natural resources for development
Ancient cultures believed demons could possess human beings
Jealousy possessed him completely after seeing them together

definitions: send mail or packages through the postal service to recipients
publish or share content on social media or online platforms
assign someone to a particular place position or military station
display or announce something publicly on a board or notice area
examples: She posted the birthday card yesterday afternoon promptly
Please post these letters on your way home
He posts travel photos on Instagram every day
The company posted updates about the service outage
The army posted soldiers at strategic border locations
They posted her to the embassy in Paris
The results were posted on the bulletin board
The restaurant posts its daily specials outside regularly

definitions: officially stamp mail with a mark showing the date and place of mailing
examples: The postal worker postmarked hundreds of letters daily
They postmarked the package with yesterday's date incorrectly

definitions: arrange for an event or action to take place at a later time than originally planned
examples: They postponed the meeting until next Monday morning
Bad weather forced them to postpone the outdoor concert

definitions: assume the existence or truth of something as a basis for reasoning or argument
suggest or propose a theory or principle as a basis for reasoning
examples: Scientists postulate the existence of dark matter particles
The theory postulates that all matter contains energy
Einstein postulated the equivalence of mass and energy
Researchers postulated a new mechanism for cell division

definitions: adopt a particular physical position or stance with the body
behave in an affected or artificial way to impress or mislead others
examples: The yoga instructor postured in various challenging positions
Soldiers posture at attention during formal ceremonies
Politicians often posture for the cameras during debates
He postures as an expert but lacks real knowledge

definitions: plant something in a pot or transfer a plant to a pot
shoot and kill game animals or birds for food
strike a ball into a pocket in billiards snooker or pool
examples: She potted the seedlings in small ceramic containers
Garden centers pot thousands of plants each spring
Hunters potted several rabbits for the evening meal
He potted a pheasant with a single shot
She potted the black ball to win the game
He carefully potted three red balls in succession

definitions: move around or work in a relaxed unhurried way doing small tasks
shape clay into pottery using hands or a wheel
examples: He pottered around the garden on Sunday mornings
She pottered in her workshop organizing art supplies
The artist pottered beautiful vases on her wheel
Students pottered bowls in their ceramics class weekly

definitions: put or store something in a pouch or pouch-like container
form or bulge into a pouch-like shape or appearance
examples: The kangaroo pouched her joey for several months
He pouched the coins in his leather bag
His cheeks pouched when filled with food completely
The fabric pouched at the knees from wear

definitions: strike or hit something heavily and repeatedly with force
crush or grind something into powder or small pieces forcefully
beat or throb with a strong regular rhythm often from exertion
confine stray animals in an enclosure until claimed by owners
examples: She pounded the door demanding to be let in
Waves pounded the rocky shore during the storm
The chef pounded the spices in a mortar
They pounded the grain into fine flour manually
His heart pounded after climbing the steep stairs
Her head pounded with a terrible migraine headache
Officials pounded stray dogs found wandering the streets
The farmer pounded the neighbor's escaped cattle temporarily

definitions: cause liquid to flow from a container in a steady stream
rain heavily in a continuous downpour of water
come or go continuously in large numbers or quantities
examples: She poured coffee into everyone's cup carefully
Water poured from the broken pipe continuously
It poured all day ruining our picnic plans
The rain poured down flooding the streets quickly
Fans poured into the stadium for the championship
Complaints poured in after the service disruption

definitions: apply powder to the face body or other surface for cosmetic purposes
crush or grind something into a fine powder or dust
examples: She powdered her nose before the photo shoot
The baker powdered the cookies with confectioner's sugar
They powdered the dried herbs for the remedy
Machines powder the minerals for industrial use efficiently

definitions: supply a device or machine with mechanical or electrical energy to operate
move with great speed or force using strength or engine power
examples: Solar panels power the entire house year-round efficiently
Batteries power the remote control for the television
The athlete powered through the final lap strongly
The speedboat powered across the lake at dawn

definitions: perform an activity or skill repeatedly to improve proficiency or maintain ability
work in a particular profession especially law or medicine
habitually follow or observe a custom tradition or religion
examples: Musicians practice scales daily to maintain their technique
The team practices every afternoon before competitions
She practices law at a downtown firm successfully
He practiced medicine in rural areas for decades
They practice Buddhism and meditate every morning peacefully
The community practices ancient traditions passed down generations

definitions: perform an activity or skill repeatedly to improve proficiency or maintain ability
work in a particular profession especially law or medicine
habitually follow or observe a custom tradition or religion
examples: Musicians practise scales daily to maintain their technique
The team practises every afternoon before competitions
She practises law at a downtown firm successfully
He practised medicine in rural areas for decades
They practise Buddhism and meditate every morning peacefully
The community practises ancient traditions passed down generations

definitions: express warm approval or admiration for someone's achievements or qualities
express reverence and adoration for a deity through worship
examples: Critics praised her performance in the leading role
The teacher praised students for their hard work
The congregation praised God through songs and prayers
They praised the Lord for their many blessings

definitions: play a mischievous trick or practical joke on someone for amusement
examples: Students pranked their teacher on April Fools' Day
They pranked their friend by hiding his car keys

definitions: catch prawns using nets or traps in coastal or marine waters
examples: Local fishermen prawn in the bay every morning
They prawned all night using specialized trawling nets

definitions: address a deity or saint with adoration confession or thanksgiving requests
hope very much that something will happen or be the case
examples: She prays every morning before starting her day
The congregation prayed together for world peace
We pray that the surgery will be successful
Parents prayed for their children's safe return home

definitions: deliver a sermon or religious address to an assembled group of people
earnestly advocate or promote an idea cause or course of action
examples: The minister preaches every Sunday morning at church
She preached about forgiveness and compassion yesterday
He constantly preaches the importance of regular exercise
Don't preach to me about healthy eating habits

definitions: make introductory or preliminary remarks before the main topic or action
examples: The speaker preambled for ten minutes before addressing the issue
She preambled with historical context before presenting findings

definitions: come or occur before something else in time order or position
walk or go in front of someone as a guide or escort
examples: The economic crisis preceded the political upheaval significantly
A brief introduction precedes each chapter in the book
The guide preceded us through the narrow mountain path
The honor guard preceded the dignitaries into the hall
